What is a key limitation to be aware of when creating a currency from an ID in Verus?

One important limitation to be aware of is that you cannot create a currency from an ID that has a properly encoded i-address as its actual name, not its calculated ID. This is because using an i-address as a currency name will only be interpreted as referring to the currency or identity that has that i-address calculated based on its name registration.

#### Limitations in multi-currency to be aware of:
1. (GUI and CLI) You will not be able to make a currency from an ID that has a properly encoded i-address as its actual name, not its calculated ID. Generally, the advice is “don’t do that”. Using an i-address when referring to a currency will only be interpreted as referring to the currency or identity which has that i-address calculated based on its name registration. As a general rule, making an ID with an i-address as its name is not prevented by the protocol, but will cause problems whenever an i-address or name may be used (many cases) and will not be supported for creating currencies. To reduce any potential for user confusion, even though the naming system provides will also be expanding the set of characters that will not be allowed for currency registrations.2. (GUI) If a currency is supported in the Verus Desktop already, such as BTC or ETH, you will not be able to use those same named currencies as a PBaaS chain. This limitation is considered errata for this testnet release and will not be a limitation before mainnet availability.### DisclaimerThis is experimental and unfinished software. Use at your own risk! No warranty for any kind of damage!

Why is it advised to avoid using an i-address as an ID name in Verus?

It is advised to avoid using an i-address as an ID name in Verus because it can cause problems whenever an i-address or name may be used, and it will not be supported for creating currencies. This can lead to user confusion, and to mitigate this, the naming system will also be expanding the set of characters that will not be allowed for currency registrations.

#### Limitations in multi-currency to be aware of:
1. (GUI and CLI) You will not be able to make a currency from an ID that has a properly encoded i-address as its actual name, not its calculated ID. Generally, the advice is “don’t do that”. Using an i-address when referring to a currency will only be interpreted as referring to the currency or identity which has that i-address calculated based on its name registration. As a general rule, making an ID with an i-address as its name is not prevented by the protocol, but will cause problems whenever an i-address or name may be used (many cases) and will not be supported for creating currencies. To reduce any potential for user confusion, even though the naming system provides will also be expanding the set of characters that will not be allowed for currency registrations.2. (GUI) If a currency is supported in the Verus Desktop already, such as BTC or ETH, you will not be able to use those same named currencies as a PBaaS chain. This limitation is considered errata for this testnet release and will not be a limitation before mainnet availability.### DisclaimerThis is experimental and unfinished software. Use at your own risk! No warranty for any kind of damage!

What is a current limitation in the Verus Desktop GUI regarding PBaaS chains?

Currently, in the Verus Desktop GUI, if a currency is already supported, such as BTC or ETH, you will not be able to use those same named currencies as a PBaaS chain. This limitation is considered errata and will be resolved before mainnet availability.

#### Limitations in multi-currency to be aware of:

What kind of software is Verus, and what kind of warranty does it provide?

Verus is experimental and unfinished software. It provides no warranty for any kind of damage, and users should use it at their own risk. However, the software is open-source and allows users to use, copy, modify, merge, publish, distribute, sublicense, and/or sell copies of the Software, subject to certain conditions.
